page_analysis.text_content:
Daylight
plane

Primary daylight plane (sides)

The daylight plane in
conjunction with the
setbacks & height
limits, create an
invisible tent

The primary daylight plane regulates structures located within the buildable area.
Structures located in the rear and/or side yards are regulated by the accessory-
structure daylight plan described on the next page.

Fig 20 Front elevation showing side primary daylight plane

intended to contain
development on the lot
in a way that preserves
privacy and exposure to
natural light.

Existing grade of the structure
(at midpoint of wall)

Notes:

• Daylight plane is measured from average grade.

• Average grade is established using existing
  grade—before any grading or fill (See Fig 44 p. 42)

• Side daylight plane is measured (up) at lot line.

• Rear daylight plane is measured (up) at rear setback.

Side lot line

24' max. for protrusions

*

Max. building height

visual_elements.description: A small, white line-art diagram on a grey background depicting a simple 3D wireframe of a house-shaped structure with a gambrel roof, referred to as an 'invisible tent'.

Figure 20: 'Front elevation showing side primary daylight plane'. This is a detailed architectural diagram showing the front elevation of two adjacent houses on sloped ground. It illustrates the concept of the daylight plane. Key elements shown include: a dashed line representing the daylight plane originating 10 feet above average grade at the side lot line and extending upwards at a 45-degree angle into the property. Vertical lines indicate the 'Side lot line'. Dimension lines show '24' max. for protrusions' and 'Max. building height'. Labels point to 'Average grade', 'Grade at the nearest point on the adjacent lot', and 'Existing grade of the structure (at midpoint of wall)'. A label near a chimney indicates 'Max. allowed is Min. required by Building Code'. An asterisk is next to the 'Max. building height' label.
visual_elements.location: Center and right side of the page

additional_notes: The page has a two-column layout: a narrow, grey-background sidebar on the left and a wider main content area on the right.
The page number '26' is located at the bottom of the left sidebar.
An asterisk (*) is present next to the 'Max. building height' dimension line, but no corresponding footnote or explanation is provided on the page.
The image is a clean, high-quality digital or photocopied page with no handwritten annotations or stamps.
cross_references: accessory-structure daylight plan described on the next page.
